citeinfo.title: Data release of Three-Dimensional Hydrogeologic Framework Model of the Rio Grande Transboundary Region of New Mexico and Texas, USA and Northern Chihuahua, Mexico
Three-Dimensional Hydrogeologic Framework Model of the Rio Grande Transboundary Region of New Mexico and Texas, USA, and Northern Chihuahua, Mexico

serinfo.sername: U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report

descript.abstract: This digital dataset represents the three-dimensional hydrogeologic framework for the Rio Grande Transboundary region of New Mexico, Texas, USA, and Northern Chihuahua, Mexico. The data define the elevation, thickness, extent, and character of the principal hydrostratigraphic units of the region, and faults and igneous intrusive dikes that cut these units. The digital data describe the following five hydrostratigraphic units: RC, river channel alluvium; three informal subdivisions of the Santa Fe Group (USF, Upper Santa Fe Group; MSF, Middle Santa Fe Group; LSF, Lower Santa Fe Group); and BSMT, which includes all pre-Santa Fe Group rocks (basement). All units except BSMT (RC, USF, MSF, LSF) are split into two subunits. In each case, the designation 1 (e.g., USF1) indicates the UPPER subunit and the designation 2 (e.g., USF2) indicates the LOWER subunit. Most of the three-dimensional hydrogeologic framework data are contained within a single polygon feature class Frmwk_cells, which contains a mesh of polygons that represent model cells that have multiple attributes including X, Y, elevation and thickness of each hydrostratigraphic unit or subunit, and codes that represent sedimentary facies for each hydrostratigraphic subunit. The spatial extent of RC, USF, MSF, and LSF are provided as separate polygon feature classes. Faults and igneous intrusive dikes are provided as separate line features classes. This digital dataset was created as part of a U.S. Geological Survey study, done in cooperation with the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, to be used as the digital hydrogeologic input data for numerical simulation of the groundwater system of the Rio Grande transboundary region of New Mexico, Texas, USA and Northern Chihuahua, Mexico. These data are intended as the digital hydrogeologic input for numerical simulation of the groundwater system. Elevation, thickness, and extent of the hydrostratigraphic units define the geohydrologic layering of the digital framework model. Codes that represent sedimentary facies may be used as a lithologic basis for the distribution of hydraulic properties within each hydrostratigraphic unit. The location of faults and igneous intrusive dikes may be used to define the location of potential horizontal flow barriers in numerical simulation of the groundwater system.
descript.purpose: The intended uses of this dataset include, but are not limited to, natural resource modeling, mapping, and visualization applications.

procstep.procdesc: Feature class Frmwk_cells-A GIS was used to develop a polygon layer representing the model grid that was 328 columns by 912 rows. Model cells (polygons) were attributed with information that defines the geometry, extent, and character of aquifers of the model grid area.
Feature class Faults-A GIS was used to georectify page-sized images from various published sources showing fault location, and digitize, merge and edit vector line datasets.
Feature class faults-A GIS was used to create attributes consistent with published sources for fault names and recency.
Feature class Volc_dikes-A GIS was used to create and edit a vector line dataset based on a published source and expert interpretations.

Feature classes LSF_extent, MSF_extent, USF_extent, and RC_extent-To create each polygon feature class, a GIS was used to extract from the feature class Frmwk cells those cells that are within the extent of each hydrostratigraphic unit. Cells within the extent have a defined zone code value other than null, 0, or 999. Cells were merged into a single multipart polygon and exported as a one of the four listed feature classes.
Feature class Frmwk_cells-A GIS was used to calculate thickness of each hydrostratigraphic unit and subunit based on elevations of top and base of each unit or subunit.

Feature class Frmwk_cells-A GIS was used to error-check the framework cells for cases where: 1) upper hydrostratigraphic unit layer elevations are less than lower layer elevations, 2) upper hydrostratigraphic unit layer elevation are equal to lower layer elevation, 3) hydrostratigraphic units are indicated as present in the framework (unit has a defined thickness) but were coded as not present in the lithology zonecodes 3) hydrostratigraphic units are indicated as absent in the framework (unit has a zero thickness) but were coded as present in the lithology zonecodes Revisions were made to the geospatial database as needed.

overview.eaover:
GEOSPATIAL DATASETS INCLUDED IN THIS GEOSPATIAL DATABASE: FEATURE CLASSES Faults-fault lines Frmwk_cells-geologic framework model polygons LSF_extent- Lower Santa Fe Group extent polygon MSF_extent- Middle Santa Fe Group extent polygon RC_extent- River channel extent polygon USF_extent- Upper Santa Fe Group extent polygon Volc_dikes-igneous dike lines
Faults Explanation of fields: Flt_name - Fault name, compiled from annotations on source maps and cross sections, combined with names listed in the Quaternary fault and fold database of the United States. Unnamed faults have a NULL value in this field. Recency - Fault recency (age) describes if fault completely cuts the upper, middle, lower Santa Fe Group or the pre-Santa Fe Group rocks. The recency attribute lists the youngest unit that the fault cuts completely. Fault recency was determined through comparison with the USGS Quaternary fault database and through inspection of the structural offset of each fault shown on cross sections in the cited source reports. Recency attributed as one of the following text USF, Upper Santa Fe Group rocks MSF, Middle Santa Fe Group rocks LSF, Lower Santa Fe Group rocks preSF, pre-Sante Fe Group rocks
Frmwk_cells Explanation of fields: ROW-integer value of row in which cell resides, range 1-912 COL- integer value of column in which cell resides, range 1-328 NUMCELL-integer value that is unique identifier of each cell, range 1-299136 POINT_X- Easting, in meters, of cell centroid. Projection: NAD_1983_UTM_Zone_13N POINT_Y- Northing, in meters, of cell centroid. Projection: NAD_1983_UTM_Zone_13N RC1_zonecode- Zonation of the upper subdivision of river channel recent alluvium (lower subdivision, RC2, was not zoned). Zonecodes explained below. USF1_zonecode- Zonation of the upper subdivision of Upper Santa Fe Group rocks. Zonecodes explained below. USF2_zonecode- Zonation of the lower subdivision of Upper Santa Fe Group rocks. Zonecodes explained below. MSF1_zonecode- Zonation of the upper subdivision of Middle Santa Fe Group rocks. Zonecodes explained below. MSF2_zonecode- Zonation of the lower subdivision of Middle Santa Fe Group rocks. Zonecodes explained below. LSF1_zonecode- Zonation of the upper subdivision of Lower Santa Fe Group rocks. Zonecodes explained below. LSF2_zonecode- Zonation of the lower subdivision of Lower Santa Fe Group rocks. Zonecodes explained below. BSMT_zonecode- Zonation of the pre-Santa Fe Group (basement) rocks. Zonecodes explained below. ElevFTDEMR- Land surface elevation, in feet, modified from a 10-m digital elevation model (DEM). Top_RC_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of river channel recent alluvium Top_USF_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of Upper Santa Fe Group rocks (includes all post-Santa Fe Group sediments) Top_MSF_ft-Elevation, in feet, of top of Middle Santa Fe Group rocks Top_LSF_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of Lower Santa Fe Group rocks Top_BSMT_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of pre-Santa Fe Group rocks Base_RC_ft- Elevation, in feet, of base of river channel recent alluvium Base_BSMT_ft- Elevation, in feet, of the arbitrary base of pre-Santa Fe Group rocks (500-foot thickness of basement rocks) THK_RC_ft- Thickness, in feet, of river channel recent alluvium THK_USF_ft- Thickness, in feet, of Upper Santa Fe Group rocks (includes all post-Santa Fe Group sediments) THK_MSF_ft- Thickness, in feet, of Middle Santa Fe Group rocks THK_LSF_ft-Thickness, in feet, of Lower Santa Fe Group rocks THK_BSMT_ft- Thickness, in feet, of pre-Santa Fe Group rocks Top_RC1_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of the upper subdivision of river channel recent alluvium Top_RC2_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of the lower subdivision of river channel recent alluvium Top_USF1_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of the upper subdivision of Upper Santa Fe Group rocks. Elevation is equal to that of top of Upper Santa Fe Group rocks. Top_USF2_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of the lower subdivision of Upper Santa Fe Group rocks. Top_MSF1_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of the upper subdivision of Middle Santa Fe Group rocks. Elevation is equal to that of top of Middle Santa Fe Group rocks. Top_MSF2_ft-Elevation, in feet, of top of the lower subdivision of Middle Santa Fe Group rocks. Top_LSF1_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of the upper subdivision of Lower Santa Fe Group rocks. Elevation is equal to that of top of Lower Santa Fe Group rocks. Top_LSF2_ft- Elevation, in feet, of top of the lower subdivision of Lower Santa Fe Group rocks.
A NULL value of -99999 is used in an elevation field if unit is absent due to erosion at land surface, or for cells at the edge of the model domain where geologic elevations were not interpreted.
Explanation of Zonecodes for RC, USF, MSF, and LSF ZoneCode Lithofacies; dominant depositional setting Lithology, sediment texture 10 River-valley, fluvial -- basal channel deposits Pebble to cobble gravel and sand 15 Basin-floor fluvial plain Sand and pebble gravel, lenses of silty clay 20 River-valley, fluvial -- Braided plain, channel deposits Sand and pebbly sand 25 Basin-floor fluvial, locally eolian Sand; lenses of pebble sand, and silty clay 30 River-valley, fluvial -- Overbank, meander-belt, oxbow deposits Silty clay, clay, and sand 35 Basin-floor, fluvial-overbank fluvial-deltaic and playa-lake; eolian Interbedded sand and silty clay; lenses of pebbly sand 40 Eolian, basin-floor alluvial Sand and sandstone; lenses of silty sand to clay 50 Distal to medial piedmont-slope, alluvial fan Gravel, sand, silt, and clay; common loamy (sand-silt-clay) 51 River-valley, fluvial -- terrace deposits, arroyo channels, reworked distal alluvial fan Sand, gravel, silt, and clay 55 Distal to medial piedmont-slope, alluvial fan Partly indurated gravel, sand, silt, and clay; common loamy (sand-silt-clay) 60 Proximal to medial piedmont-slope, alluvial-fan Coarse gravelly, loamy sand and sandy loam; lenses of sand and cobble to boulder gravel 65 Proximal to medial piedmont-slope, alluvial-fan Partly indurated coarse gravelly, loamy sand and sandy loam; lenses of sand and cobble to boulder gravel 90 Basin-floor --alluvial flat, playa, lake, and fluvial-lacustrine; distal-piedmont alluvial Silty clay interbedded with sand, silty sand and clay 100 Basin-floor --alluvial flat, playa, lake, with evaporite processes Silty clay interbedded with sand, silty sand and clay with gypsiferous and alkali-impregnated zones 0 This code is used for units that have been eroded at the upper surface of the model and are absent, with a normal stratigraphic sequence of older units present 999 This code is used where a unit is absent within the stratigraphic stack and was given an arbitrary thickness of 5 feet. Zonecode is arbitrary; no lithologic significance is implied.
